awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2022: Understanding microbiome impact on plant performance in a warming climate.
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2022, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Stressors such as high temperature, drought, and salt can lead to reduced crop yields and billions of dollars of crop loss each year. To feed a growing global population, innovative new agricultural methods must be developed to improve plant stress tolerance and crop yield. One emerging method to meet these goals and increase crop performance in a warming climate is through design and application of climate-selected microbial communities; however, we currently have little basic understanding of how existing microbial communities (microbiomes) influence plant performance at elevated temperature. Through this proposed research, the fellow will investigate how microbial communities change inside or on the surface of a plant at elevated temperature, and the impact those changes have on plant health. In parallel, the fellow will work to improve food security through the Campus Pantry Collaborative (CPC). The CPC provides a direct outlet to share scientific findings from this project with a non-scientific audience and an opportunity to bridge the gap between social and scientific efforts to improve food security.

This project combines molecular, multi-omic, and mathematic modeling approaches to address knowledge gaps in “temperature-microbiome-plant” triangular interactions and reveal underlying principles of emergent plant and microbiome function(s) in warming conditions. Previous research suggests that microbiomes can perform specific functions in defined abiotic conditions. Separate findings show that plant physiology, development, and phenotype can be dramatically influenced by abiotic factors, such as elevated temperature. By simultaneously examining changes in microbial composition and plant performance at elevated temperature this project has the potential to reveal new principles of host-microbiome-environment interactions that could apply even beyond plant systems. Additionally, this research will be used to improve current predictive models for microbiome changes that can be directly tested in crop species. Through this project, the fellow will develop a multidisciplinary research skill set and will gain additional skills in scientific mentoring and lab management. The fellow will also refine these skills through involvement with the CPC.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The past few decades of research have greatly expanded our understanding of how plants interact with individual microbes and how plants respond to elevated temperature. However, in nature, plants, microbes, and temperature, along with other environmental variables, interact simultaneously, and we still have little understanding of how these three-way interactions impact plant health. As the climate continues to change, understanding three-way interactions in detail will be crucial for developing resilient crops and agricultural treatments. This NSF PRFB project aimed to characterize how microbiome communities change at elevated temperature in the context of a plant and the impact these changes have on plant phenotypes at elevated temperature.

Through this research, I have discovered several emergent properties with direct implications for plant health. One particularly interesting finding revealed that only at elevated temperature some microbes compromise plant cuticle integrity. The plant cuticle is a critical barrier against both abiotic and biotic stress, preventing water loss from plant leaves and most attacks from bacteria and fungi. As such, a compromised cuticle leaves plants more susceptible to disease and extreme environmental conditions, which could have negative impacts on crop yield and global food supplies. To understand this phenomenon further, I identified several microbial candidate genes that may produce molecular products with cuticle-degrading functions. The function of these microbial products will be confirmed in the near future.

In parallel, I profiled the plant response to microbial community colonization and elevated temperature across many types of Arabidopsis. The results reveal possible genetic mechanisms and plant response pathways that may contribute to compromised cuticle function with colonization at elevated temperature. This dataset will be made publicly available upon publication of the research so that others and I can probe the various mechanisms underlying plant responses to combined abiotic and biotic factors. Collectively, this project characterized microbial and plant responses to elevated temperature in the context of three-way interactions. The results substantially advance our understanding of mechanisms and phenotypes in these combined conditions and provide rich datasets on which to base many future explorations.

In addition to research, this fellowship had many broader impacts. Throughout the funding period, two graduate students and two undergraduates received training and advanced the project research goals. Additionally, I organized a professional development series for my lab group, which had two notable outcomes: 1) the development of a yearly lab climate survey to promote diversity, equity, and inclusion in our workplace, and 2) establishment of twice-yearly meetings between plant molecular groups at Duke University and UNC Chapel Hill to promote free exchange of ideas, resources, and expertise across institutions. At the department and institution level, my roles in two trainee-led groups have had a substantial impact. First, with the Duke Climate Plant Innovation Center, I recruited a team and led our effort to implement ongoing events aimed at promoting community, providing professional development, and facilitating cross-disciplinary interactions among plant-climate researchers at Duke. As a direct result of my involvement and the team’s commitment, we have hosted four events in the past year in addition to a trainee-focused seminar series to share and receive feedback on unpublished projects. These events have attracted roughly 100 researchers across multiple departments, programs, and schools at Duke. Finally, my contributions to the Campus Pantry Collaborative along with other dedicated team members contributed directly to Duke’s strategic plan for food security. As a result, Duke established the Duke Food Security Action team housed under Student Affairs and led by Deans in Student Services and Duke Dining. This represents a substantial commitment from the Duke Administration and secures the future impact of the Campus Pantry Collaborative.

Overall, this funding from the NSF PRFB has made possible significant advances in our ability to understand the basic biology of complex environmental interactions and has had broad impacts across scales for trainees, the lab, department, institution, and community. Future efforts will build on this success to define further the mechanisms behind emergent, three-way interaction phenotypes and develop solutions for agriculture in a changing climate.
